text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hello I'm carthic a technical account
manager here at the AWS office in Los
Angeles today I'm going to show you how
to use AWS swap to allow or block
traffic based on a country's geolocation
let's get started ews is a web
application firewall that helps protect
your web applications from common web
exploits that could affect application
availability compromise security or
consume excessive resources using awsw
to blog traffic is a powerful tool to
enhance the security and control of your
web applications on
AWS but why is geolocation filtering
important when you use geolocation
filtering you can control access to your
web applications based on the geographic
location of your users this is
particularly useful to enforce
compliance or to block malous traffic
from specific countries let's dive into
the steps to allow or block traffic
based on Country geolocation using
awsw after logging in to the AWS
Management console navigate to the AWS
wav
console in the navigation pain under
awsf choose web
ACLS select the web
ACL navigate to rules and select the add
rules add my own rules and Rule groups
for rule builder enter a name for your
rule for if a request choose matches the
statement for choose an inspection
option choose originates from a country
for this example I'm going to block
request originating from Japan for
choose country codes choose the country
that you want requests to be inspected
for for Action choose either to allow
request or block to block request from
the country chosen earlier in this
example we are going to block request
from Japan I'll go ahead and select the
block note when choosing to block or
allow requests consider the default
action set for the web ACL if the
default action is blocked then requests
that come from all countries are blocked
except for countries that are explicitly
allowed this is the simplest
configuration to manage the geographical
requests that are allowed however this
configuration doesn't provide an
opportunity to inspect the content of
all the request if the default action is
allow then you can create a negate rule
to specify the countries that must not
be blocked the action on this rule must
be blocked this creates a rule that
doesn't block request from the countries
that you want to to allow but also
doesn't explicitly allow them requests
must wait to pass other user defined
rules such as inspections for malicious
content before being allowed by the
default
action now let's go ahead and add the
rule note for set rule priority select
your rule and then move its priority the
rules are processed in the order that
they appear now let's save the rule when
we do so the geoblock is applied and now
you know how to use AWS to allow or
block traffic based on Country
geolocation thanks for watching and
happy cloud computing from all of us
here at AWS
[Applause]
[Music]
